pages.title: Stirling Engine
pages.text: The <item>Stirling Engine/$ is a way of producing <thing>$(l:essentials:intro/rotary)rotary power/$ from <thing>$(l:essentials:intro/heat)heat/$. Or more specifically, from a temperature difference.$(br2)The <item>stirling engine/$ has two separate heat connections- one on bottom and one on the sides. The greater the difference in temperature between

the two inputs, the more power is produced, and the more efficient the <item>stirling engine/$ is. There must be a minimum 20°C difference to produce any power. Heat will be exchanged between the two inputs- the higher the temperature difference, the faster heat is consumed (-1°C/t per 20°C difference at the hot side).$(br2)The <item>stirling engine/$ will

stop producing any power above speeds of 2rad/s [config controlled- trust the tooltip]. The <item>stirling engine/$ also has <em>no minimum temperature/$, only a minimum temperature difference.$(br2)Heat is consumed on the hot side, and produced on the cold side. However, more heat is consumed than is produced- the lost heat is mostly converted to rotary

power. The bigger the temperature difference, the more efficient this is.$(br2)By default (trust the tooltip), below 500°C temperature difference, <thing>$(l:essentials:intro/fluid)steam power/$ is more efficient per degree heat consumed. Above 500°C, the <item>stirling engine/$ is more efficient, and gets better the higher the temperature difference (capped at 2000°C).$(br2)

<page>$(br2)Tips:$(br2)-This machine is a really efficient but more complicated way to make a LOT of rotary power. For lower powers, (below 500°C temperature difference), use <thing>$(l:essentials:intro/fluid)steam power/$ instead.$(br2)-Because the speed is capped at 2rad/s, you'll probably want <item>$(l:essentials:rotary/gear_large)gearing

<item>$(l:essentials:rotary/gear_large)/$ to get higher speeds.$(br2)-If one side is room temperature, and the other side is extremely cold, this can also produce power. You can generate power from cooling instead of heating if you want.$(br2)-You can use the heat generated on the cold side to run machines, power another <item>stirling engine/$ for extra

efficiency (but the gain is tiny), or just <item>$(l:essentials:heat/sink)vent it/$.$(br2)<page>$(br2)Formulas (for nerds and min-maxers):$(br2)ΔT: Temperature difference$(br2)Qh: Heat consumed from the hot side, °C/t$(br2)
